awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RUI: Reconstructing the Plastic-to-Brittle Exhumation History of the Taiwan Metamorphic Core
awd_abstract_narration:
Taiwan represents one of the most active tectonic environments on Earth. The island marks the collision between the Luzon volcanic arc and the passive margin of Asia and for decades the collision has motivated geodynamic models to explain the evolution of many mountain belts around the world. This collision drives deformation and active uplift of the Taiwan mountain belt. Because of the very rapid uplift and high erosion rates the metamorphic core of Taiwan is exposed in the core of Taiwan's Central Range and its eastern margin. Here, a joint team of U.S. and Taiwanese scientists and students is exploring the idea that exhumation of the metamorphic rocks is facilitated by extension rather than the collision-driven shortening model that is usually invoked. The researchers will examine the geometry of the metamorphic rocks and the movement patterns of active faults to determine the mechanisms by which the rocks are exhumed. In addition to providing new insights into mountain building processes, the project advances desired societal outcomes through participation of women and underrepresented minorities in STEM; (b) development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce through undergraduate and graduate student training plus a workshop for Taiwan undergraduate students; and (c) increased partnerships through international collaboration.

More specifically, the objective of this project is to document the plastic-to-brittle exhumation history of the metamorphic core of Taiwan. The metamorphic core (the Tananao schist) in the eastern Central Range is marked by characteristics that are difficult to explain in the context of a steady-state, doubly-vergent orogenic wedge; the current prevailing model. In most parts of the mountain belt, metamorphic foliations are steeply dipping, forming a regional cleavage fan that is east dipping in the west and west dipping in the east. Close to the collisional suture (Longitudinal Valley) this simple pattern breaks down and the youngest metamorphic foliation is commonly gently dipping. Moreover, most mesoscale faults observed to date in this area record normal displacement and accommodate NE-SW extension, the same extension direction as recorded in crustal earthquakes. The researchers aim to test the hypothesis that normal displacement faults and shear zones accommodate syn-collision exhumation of the metamorphic core in eastern Taiwan. This will entail systematically documenting the geometry and kinematics of the youngest metamorphic fabrics and overprinting brittle structures in the Tananao Schist, and establishing the relation between the plastic-to-brittle deformation patterns and ongoing deformation as constrained by seismotectonics and seismic tomography. The research team composed U.S. and Taiwanese scientists and graduate and undergraduate students will collect metamorphic fabric data, and oriented rock samples for petrographic and XCT analyses. Kinematic data for ductile shear zones and overprinting brittle structures, e.g., faults and joints, will also be collected. The existing catalog of earthquake focal mechanisms will be supplemented with new mechanisms generated from Taiwan Central Weather Bureau data. The results will be integrated with seismic tomography and seismotectonic constraints on active deformation to better understand the mechanisms behind exhumation of Taiwan?s metamorphic core.

por.por_cntn:
The Central Range of Taiwan is one of the fastest rising mountain belts on Earth. This results in extremely steep landscapes that are subject to climate- and earthquake-induced landslides, pressing hazards that highlight the need to engage more Taiwanese undergraduates in work aimed at understanding the geology of the Central Range. At the same time, the nature of bedrock structures that accommodate the high uplift rate has remained elusive. This project connected U.S. undergraduates with Taiwanese undergraduates to document bedrock structures that formed as the rocks moved upward across the boundary separating warmer (ductile) and cooler (brittle) conditions (passing the so-called ductile-brittle transition).

The key intellectual outcomes of the project shed light on fundamental mountain building processes (Hsu et al., 2022; Synorogenic extension and extrusion in southern Taiwan; Tectonophysics). First, we document that the shallow crust at high elevations is stretching horizontally toward the southwest. At lower elevations the shallow crust is being horizontally shortened by impingement between a southeastward-pointing continental promontory (the Peikang high on the Eurasian plate) and the colliding Luzon Island chain (on the Philippine Sea plate).  We show that that horizontal stretching reflects lateral extrusion of the north-northeast trending Central Range toward the southwest.

 We also show that this extrusion process started when the rocks were deep enough to behave by ductile processes, and that it persisted as the rocks were uplifted to the surface where brittle processes dominate. The youngest throughgoing rock texture (a layering referred to as foliation) formed during ductile deformation is cut by, and cuts, brittle features including fractures and faults that record the same southwestward stretching direction. These coeval structures collectively record the upward movement of the Central Range across the ductile-brittle transition. The same southwestward extrusion process continues to the present as indicated by recent detailed topographic surveys and by modeling of earthquake data.   

Integration of rock cooling age data with recent plate motion reconstructions suggests that the high uplift rates of the Central Range may have begun as recently as 0.5 million years ago. This timing challenges the existing paradigm that argues that uplift was initiated in northern Taiwan ca. 5 to 6 million years ago.

The broader impacts of this project were far reaching. To showcase the importance of studying bedrock geology in the Central Range of Taiwan, we worked with our collaborators in Taipei to offer an undergraduate workshop held in January 2020. We assembled >20 Taiwanese undergraduate students, several Taiwanese faculty, graduate students, and postdocs, 1 U.S. graduate student and 2 U.S. undergraduate students for 2 days of lectures, posters, and hands-on microscope work at National Taipei University of Technology (see workshop flyer). We then held a 2-day field trip to the Taroko Gorge in the eastern Central Range (see field photo).

 During the course of this project, 6 of my Indiana University of Pennsylvania (IUP) undergraduates contributed meaningfully to the research, 4 of whom travelled to Taiwan to assist with data collection and sampling. All 4 of these students graduated from IUP and have continued with graduate studies in GIS, hydrogeology, or marine geophysics. Two additional students continue to work on samples and data from the project, and both have indicated interest in continuing their studies.  Importantly, all the students were actively engaged in this project as undergraduates at IUP, a predominantly undergraduate institution. They consistently participated in my weekly undergraduate-only research group meetings. Two of the students contributed to our IUP Undergraduate Summer Opportunity for Applying Research (U-SOAR) program, and 1 first-generation student earned a prestigious Goldwater Scholarship. The enrichment that these students provided to the IUP community of scholars was substantial and inspiring (see IUP media item).
